dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: David, I was just looking at my savings account interest rate and thinking about how it's all tied to these central bank decisions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: David, I was just looking at my savings account interest rate and thinking about how it's all tied to these central bank decisions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And speaking of that, the National Bank of Kazakhstan just announced they're keeping their base rate at 16.5 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And speaking of that, the National Bank of Kazakhstan just announced they're keeping their base rate at sixteen point five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Thursday, June 5, the Monetary Policy Committee of the National Bank decided to keep the base rate at 16.5 percent per annum with an interest rate corridor of +/- 1 percentage point, leaving it unchanged.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, yeah, they held it steady again. That's the rate they use to lend to commercial banks, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, yeah, they held it steady again. That's the rate they use to lend to commercial banks, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The base rate is the percentage at which the National Bank lends short-term funds to commercial banks and accepts their deposits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's a huge deal because it basically sets the tone for borrowing costs across the whole economy—like for mortgages, business loans, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's a huge deal because it basically sets the tone for borrowing costs across the whole economy-like for mortgages, business loans, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It plays a crucial role in setting borrowing costs for consumers and influences inflation levels in the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So when they keep it high like this, it's kind of like putting a brake on inflation, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So when they keep it high like this, it's kind of like putting a brake on inflation, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversely, raising the rate helps curb inflation by reducing the money supply and encouraging savings over spending and investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. It makes borrowing more expensive, so people and businesses spend less, which can help cool down price increases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. It makes borrowing more expensive, so people and businesses spend less, which can help cool down price increases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then on the flip side, if they lower it, loans get cheaper, which can boost spending and investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then on the flip side, if they lower it, loans get cheaper, which can boost spending and investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A lower rate injects more money into the economy, making loans cheaper for businesses, increasing investments, and stimulating economic growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Though lowering it might also weaken the tenge a bit in the short term if investors move money elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Though lowering it might also weaken the tenge a bit in the short term if investors move money elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A reduction in the base rate may weaken the national currency in the short term, as cheaper money can prompt investors to sell off tenge assets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm. And they mentioned the next review is scheduled for July 11 next year, right? That's quite a gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm. And they mentioned the next review is scheduled for July eleven next year, right? That's quite a gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next scheduled decision on the base rate will be announced on July 11, 2025, at 12:00 p.m.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, July 11, 2025 at noon. Gives everyone some time to see how the current policy plays out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, July eleven, twenty twenty five at noon. Gives everyone some time to see how the current policy plays out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next scheduled decision on the base rate will be announced on July 11, 2025, at 12:00 p.m.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how such a single number can have so many ripple effects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how such a single number can have so many ripple effects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's like the heartbeat of monetary policy—everything else just kind of follows from there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's like the heartbeat of monetary policy-everything else just kind of follows from there.
